sn5.5:1.2: Then the nun Uppalavanna robed up in the morning …
sn5.5:1.3: and stood at the root of a sal tree in full flower.
sn5.5:1.4: Then Mara the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Uppalavanna feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from immersion, went up to her and addressed her in verse:
sn5.5:2.1: “You’ve come to this sal tree all crowned with flowers,
sn5.5:2.2: and stand at its root all alone, O nun.
sn5.5:2.3: Your beauty is second to none—
sn5.5:2.4: silly girl, aren’t you afraid of rascals?”
sn5.5:3.2: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
sn5.5:3.4: “This is Mara the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from immersion!”
sn5.5:3.5: Then Uppalavanna, knowing that this was Mara the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
sn5.5:4.3: I’d stir not a hair nor panic.
sn5.5:4.4: I’m not scared of you, Mara, even alone.
sn5.5:5.3: I could stand between your eyebrows
sn5.5:5.4: and you still wouldn’t see me.
sn5.5:6.1: I’m the master of my own mind,
sn5.5:6.2: I’ve developed the bases of psychic power well.
sn5.5:6.4: and I’m not afraid of you, sir!”
sn5.5:7.1: Then Mara the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Uppalavanna knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
